facts.text: Appeal arises out of S.L.P (C) No.3358 of 2007

anchor.surface_text: O R D E R Arising out of S.L.P C  No.3358 of 2007 Heard learned companynsel for the parties. Leave granted.

facts.text: Judgment and order dated 17th February, 2006 passed by Single Judge of High Court of Punjab and Haryana in R.S.A. No.666/2006

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment and order dated 17th February, 2006 passed by a learned Single Judge of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana in R.S.A. No.666/2006 whereby the learned Single Judge has affirmed the judgment and decree passed by the First Appellate Court.

facts.text: Plaintiffs-respondents appointed as Mali (gardener) in service of defendant-appellant (golf club run by Haryana Tourism Corporation) in 1989 and 1988 respectively on daily wages

anchor.surface_text: The brief facts which are necessary for the disposal of the present appeal are that the plaintiffs  respondents in this appeal  were appointed as Mali  gardener  in the service of the defendant-appellant, which is a golf club run by the Haryana Tourism Corporation in the year 1989 and 1988 respectively on daily wages.

facts.text: In 1989 plaintiffs told to perform duties of Tractor Drivers though no post of tractor driver in employer's establishment

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently in the year 1989 they were told to perform the duties of Tractor Drivers, though there was numberpost of tractor driver in the employers establishment.

facts.text: Plaintiffs continued to be paid wages for post of Mali for a number of years

anchor.surface_text: However for a number of years they companytinued to be paid wages for the post of Mali.

facts.text: On recommendation by Head Office, appellants started paying plaintiffs wages of tractor driver on daily wage basis per rates recommended by Deputy Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on a recommendation made by the Head Office, the appellants started paying them wages of tractor driver on daily wage basis, as per rates recommended by the Deputy Commissioner.

facts.text: Plaintiffs continued to work as tractor drivers for about a decade

anchor.surface_text: Though they companytinued to work for about a decade as tractor drivers, their services were regularized against the post of Mali in the year 1999

facts.text: Services of plaintiffs regularized against post of Mali in 1999

anchor.surface_text: their services were regularized against the post of Mali in the year 1999 and number as tractor driver.

facts.text: Respondents filed civil suit in April 2001 claiming regularization against posts of tractor driver

anchor.surface_text: When despite representations their grievance was number redressed, the respondents herein filed civil suit in the month of April, 2001 claiming regularization against the posts of tractor driver.

facts.text: Trial Court rejected claim, observed no post of tractor driver, plying tractor part of Mali job in Golf Club, dismissed suit

anchor.surface_text: Their claim was rejected by the Trial Court which observed that there was numberpost of tractor driver in the establishment, and the suit was dismissed. The Trial Court held that plying a tractor is part and parcel of the job of Mali in a Golf Club, since the Golf Field of the Club is vast and needs to be maintained with mechanical gadgets.

facts.text: First Appellate Court (Additional District Judge, Faridabad) accepted appeal, set aside Trial Court judgment, directed defendants to get post of tractor driver sanctioned and regularize plaintiffs

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved against the said order of dismissal of the suit, the respondents herein preferred an appeal before the Additional District Judge, Faridabad. Their appeal was accepted and the judgment and decree of the Trial Court was set aside. The First Appellate Court observed that the defendants were taking the work of tractor driver from the plaintiffs since 13.8.1999, and hence it directed the defendants to get the post of tractor driver sanctioned, and to regularize the plaintiffs on that post.

facts.text: High Court Single Judge dismissed second appeal, affirmed First Appellate Court, held post of tractor driver should be created

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Divisional Manager, Aravali Golf Club filed a second appeal before the High Court of Punjab and Haryana. The learned Single Judge held that the post of tractor driver should be created as there is numberhitch in number creating the posts of drivers especially when tractors were available and there existed need to use those tractors.

facts.text: Plaintiffs admitted in plaint appointed as Mali

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff-respondents admitted in the plaint that they were appointed as Mali.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 filed Writ Petition No.6216/1991 for regularizing services

anchor.surface_text: The respondent No.1 had earlier filed Writ Petition No.6216/1991 for regularizing his services. The Honble High Court disposed of the said writ petition by passing the order directing the respondent No.1 to make a representation against the termination of his services

facts.text: High Court disposed writ petition directing representation against termination, restrained termination till decided

anchor.surface_text: The Honble High Court disposed of the said writ petition by passing the order directing the respondent No.1 to make a representation against the termination of his services and the appellants herein were restrained from terminating the services of the respondent No.1 till his representation was decided.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 made representation for regularization on 2.5.1991

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the said order the respondent No.1 made representation for regularization of his service on 2.5.1991.

facts.text: Plaintiff-respondent informed vide order dated 14.5.1991 no post of tractor driver, case considered when post available

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff- respondent was informed vide order dated 14.5.1991 that there was numberpost of tractor driver and his case for regularization would be companysidered as and when sanctioned post of the tractor deriver will be available.

facts.text: Plaintiff No.1 paid wages of tractor driver from August 1990 to 11.5.1999 on daily wage basis on D.C. rate

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff-respondent was paid wages of tractor deriver from August 1990 to 11.5.1999 on daily wage basis on D.C. rate as he was asked to work as a tractor driver.

facts.text: Services of plaintiff No.1 regularized as Mali vide order dated 11.5.1999, accepted without protest

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile services of plaintiff No.1 was regularized as Mali vide order dated 11.5.1999 which was duly accepted by him without any protest.

facts.text: Respondent No.2 engaged as Mali on daily wage basis w.e.f. 1.9.1988, regularized as Mali on 11.5.1999

anchor.surface_text: Similar is the case of respondent No.2 herein. He was engaged as Mali on daily wage basis w.e.f. 1.9.1988 and his services were also regularized as Mali vide order dated 11.5.1999.

facts.text: No sanctioned post of tractor driver in appellants' establishment, undisputed

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that there is numbersanctioned post of tractor driver in the appellants establishment.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no sanctioned post of tractor driver, courts cannot direct creation of posts

anchor.surface_text: Since there is numbersanctioned post of tractor driver against which the respondents companyld be regularized as tractor driver, the direction of the First Appellate Court and the learned Single Judge to create the post of tractor driver and regularizing the services of the respondents against the said newly created posts was in our opinion companypletely beyond their jurisdiction.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court and First Appellate Court judgments, upholds Trial Court, dismisses suit

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the directions given by the High Court and First Appellate Court to create the posts of tractor driver and regularize the services of the respondents against the said posts cannot be sustained and are hereby set aside. Consequently, this appeal is allowed and the judgment and order of the High Court as well as that of the First Appellate Court are set aside and the judgment of the Trial Court is upheld. The suit is dismissed.
O R D E R Arising out of S.L.P C  No.3358 of 2007 Heard learned companynsel for the parties. Leave granted.

This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment and order dated 17th February, 2006 passed by a learned Single Judge of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana in R.S.A. No.666/2006 whereby the learned Single Judge has affirmed the judgment and decree passed by the First Appellate Court.

concepts.interpretation: Second appeal lies only if substantial question of law arises

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: Additional District Judge, Faridabad. Their appeal was accepted and the judgment and decree of the Trial Court was set aside. The First Appellate Cour

concepts.unlisted_description: Second appeal on substantial question of law

anchor.surface_text: The respondent No.1 had earlier filed Writ Petition No.6216/1991 for regularizing his services. The Honble High Court disposed of the said writ petition by passing the order directing the respondent No.1 to make a representation against the termination of his services

Since there is nosanctioned post of tractor driver against which the respondents could be regularized as tractor driver, the direction of the First Appellate Court and the learned Single Judge to create the post of tractor driver and regularizing the services of the respondents against the said newly created posts was in our opinion completely beyond their jurisdiction. The Court cannot direct the creation of posts. Creation and sanction of posts is a prerogative of the executive or legislative authorities and the court cannot arrogate to itself this purely executive or legislative function, and direct creation of posts in any organization. This Court has time and again pointed out that the creation of a post is an executive or legislative function and it involves economic factors. Hence the Courts cannot take upon themselves the power of creation of a post.

concepts.interpretation: Courts lack jurisdiction to direct executive/legislative authorities to create or sanction posts as it is purely executive/legislative function involving economic considerations

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: s cannot be regularized in the said post. This is a finding of fact recorded by the Trial Court and it was never disputed at any stage. Aggrieved agai

concepts.unlisted_label: Courts cannot direct creation of posts
concepts.unlisted_description: Creation and sanctioning of posts is prerogative of executive or legislature; courts cannot arrogate this function

anchor.surface_text: Before parting with this case we would like to make some observations about the limits of the powers of the judiciary. We are compelled to make these observations because we are repeatedly coming across cases where Judges are unjustifiably trying to perform executive or legislative functions. In our opinion this is clearly unconstitutional. In the name of judicial activism Judges cannot cross their limits and try to take over functions which belong to another organ of the State. Judges must exercise judicial restraint and must not encroach into the executive or legislative domain vide Indian Drugs Pharmaceuticals Ltd. vs. The Workman of Indian Drugs Pharmaceuticals Ltd.  2007  1 SCC 408 and S.C. Chandra and Ors. vs. State of Jharkhand and Ors. JT 2007  10  4 SC 272  See concurring judgment of M. Katju, J. . Under our Constitution, the Legislature, Executive and Judiciary all have their own broad spheres of operation.

concepts.interpretation: Legislature, executive, judiciary have distinct spheres; no organ should encroach on another's domain to maintain constitutional balance

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ecutive or legislative authorities and the Court cannot arrogate to itself this purely executive or legislative function, and direct creation of posts

concepts.unlisted_description: Broad separation of powers under Constitution; organs must respect each other's domains

anchor.surface_text: Judges must exercise judicial restraint and must not encroach into the executive or legislative domain vide Indian Drugs Pharmaceuticals Ltd. vs. The Workman of Indian Drugs Pharmaceuticals Ltd.

concepts.interpretation: Judges must know limits, exercise modesty and humility, avoid running government or encroaching other organs

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ecutive or legislative authorities and the Court cannot arrogate to itself this purely executive or legislative function, and direct creation of posts

concepts.unlisted_description: Self-imposed discipline on judiciary to avoid overreach into executive/legislative functions

anchor.surface_text: Judicial review is a powerful weapon to restrain unconstitutional exercise of power by the legislature and executive. The expanding horizon of judicial review has taken in its fold the concept of social and economic justice.

concepts.interpretation: Judiciary ensures legislature and executive function within constitutional limits; subject to self-restraint

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge held that the post of tractor driver should be created as there is no hitch in creating the posts of drivers especially when tractors were available and there existed need to use those tractors. It was also observed by the learned Single Judge that simply by relying upon technicalities the State authorities cannot be allowed to suppress the individuals and to deny their lawful rights. The learned Single Judge also held that nosubstantial question of law arose in the matter.

anchor.surface_text: Before parting with this case we would like to make some observations about the limits of the powers of the judiciary. We are compelled to make these observations because we are repeatedly coming across cases where Judges are unjustifiably trying to perform executive or legislative functions. In our opinion this is clearly unconstitutional.

arguments.claim: Broad separation of powers under Constitution; no organ should encroach on another's domain

anchor.surface_text: Under our Constitution, the Legislature, Executive and Judiciary all have their own broad spheres of operation. Ordinarily it is not proper for any of these three organs of the State to encroach upon the domain of another, otherwise the delicate balance in the Constitution will be upset, and there will be a reaction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No sanctioned post of tractor driver exists and respondents unable to show any; courts cannot direct regularization against non-existent post

holdings.text: The Court cannot direct the creation of posts; creation and sanction of posts is a prerogative of the executive or legislative authorities

anchor.surface_text: The Court cannot direct the creation of posts. Creation and sanction of posts is a prerogative of the executive or legislative authorities and the Court cannot arrogate to itself this purely executive or legislative function, and direct creation of posts in any organization. This Court has time and again pointed out that the creation of a post is an executive or legislative function and it involves economic factors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Creation of posts involves economic factors and is purely executive/legislative function; courts cannot arrogate this power, as per precedents

holdings.text: The directions given by the High Court and First Appellate Court to create the posts of tractor driver and regularize the services of the respondents against the said posts cannot be sustained and are set aside; appeal allowed, judgment of Trial Court upheld, suit dismissed

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the directions given by the High Court and First Appellate Court to create the posts of tractor driver and regularize the services of the respondents against the said posts cannot be sustained and are hereby set aside. Consequently, this appeal is allowed and the judgment and order of the High Court as well as that of the First Appellate Court are set aside and the judgment of the Trial Court is upheld. The suit is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts exceeded jurisdiction by directing creation of non-existent posts; Trial Court correctly dismissed suit for lack of sanctioned post

holdings.text: Judges must exercise judicial restraint and must not encroach into the executive or legislative domain

anchor.surface_text: Judges must exercise judicial restraint and must not encroach into the executive or legislative domain vide Indian Drugs Pharmaceuticals Ltd. vs. The Workman of Indian Drugs Pharmaceuticals Ltd.  2007  1 SCC 408 and S.C. Chandra and Ors. vs. State of Jharkhand and Ors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repeated instances of judges performing executive/legislative functions unconstitutional; citing precedents on restraint

holdings.text: Under the Constitution, Legislature, Executive and Judiciary have broad spheres of operation and no organ should encroach on another's domain

anchor.surface_text: Under our Constitution, the Legislature, Executive and Judiciary all have their own broad spheres of operation. Ordinarily it is not proper for any of these three organs of the State to encroach upon the domain of another, otherwise the delicate balance in the Constitution will be upset, and there will be a reaction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad separation of powers essential to constitutional balance; encroachment leads to reaction; quoting Montesquieu

holdings.text: Judicial review must be exercised with self-imposed restraint; courts cannot direct executive in policy matters or create laws

anchor.surface_text: Judicial review is a powerful weapon to restrain unconstitutional exercise of power by the legislature and executive. ... While exercise of powers by the legislature and executive is subject to judicial restraint, the only check on our own exercise of power is the self imposed discipline of judicial restraint.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judiciary ensures constitutional limits but subject to self-restraint; cannot advise on policy or legislate; citing US and Indian precedents
